</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="WIDTH:567PX">
<A NAME="eolPage114"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-SIZE:11PT; PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS" ALIGN=CENTER>
<B>
	TRANSPORTADORA DE GAS DEL SUR S.A.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
	Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements as of December 31, 2015 and comparative information
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-SIZE:8PT" ALIGN=CENTER>
	(Stated in thousands of pesos as described in Note 3, unless otherwise stated)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-BOTTOM:4PX; BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:46.933PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
<B>
	12.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:46.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:37.733PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	LOANS
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Short-term and long-term loans as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 comprise the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS089.GIF" ALT="[TGS089.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=223.733 WIDTH=383.2>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX">
	The breakdown of loans based on its currency of origin is the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:-47.267PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-37.867PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS091.GIF" ALT="[TGS091.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=70.133 WIDTH=383.2>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The activity of the loans as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 is the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:CG TIMES,TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN=CENTER>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS093.GIF" ALT="[TGS093.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=121.067 WIDTH=383.2>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The maturities of the current and non-current loans as of December 31, 2015 are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:88PX; FONT-FAMILY:CG TIMES,TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	&nbsp;
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS095.GIF" ALT="[TGS095.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=127.733 WIDTH=328.867>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<U>
	Issuance of notes under the 2007 Global Program (the &#147;2007 Program&#148;):
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Extraordinary Shareholders&#146; meeting held on December 21, 2006 approved the creation of the 2007 Global Program for the issuance of new notes up to a maximum aggregate amount of US$ 650.0 million. The 2007 Program was authorized by the CNV on January 18, 2007.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Accordingly, between May and June 2007, the Company refinanced its outstanding indebtedness through the issuance of US$500.0 million new notes (the &#147;2007 Notes&#148;), the early prepayment of its outstanding debt through an exchange offer, the cancellation of outstanding notes which did not participate in the exchange offer and cancellation of bank loans. The Company&#146;s goal in issuing these notes was to improve the Company&#146;s financial indebtedness profile and to ease the restrictions imposed by the prior debt restructured in 2004, including but not limited to dividend distribution, additional indebtedness and capital expenditures.
<FONT STYLE="BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFF00">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The 2007 Notes have a coupon rate of 7.875%, with interest being paid semiannually, and maturity date of May 2017. Principal on the 2007 Notes is to be paid in four equal annual installments beginning in May 2014 until maturity. The 2007 Notes are traded in the
<I>
	Bolsa de Comercio de Buenos Aires
</I>
	(&quot;BCBA&quot;), the
<I>
	Mercado Abierto Electr&#243;nico
</I>
	(&#147;MAE&#148;) and the Euro MTF of the Luxembourg Exchange.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Moreover, between August 2008 and August 2010, considering favorable conditions in the market, the Company reduced its financial indebtedness through the cancellation of a portion of the 2007 Notes for an aggregate amount of US$ 125,976,000, which had previously been purchased on the market at a lower price.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On January 10, 2014, TGS launched an offer to exchange its outstanding 2007 Notes for newly issued notes under the 2014 Global Program (the &#147;2014 Global Program&#148;), as it is described below. The period of acceptance of this offer expired on February 7, 2014. The percentage of acceptance received amounted to 67%. As a result of the exchange, a total US$ 123,283,000 of the 2007 Notes remained outstanding and thus, the amortization payments are expected to amount to US$ 30,820,750. After its first amortization in May 2014, as December 31, 2015, 2007 Notes amounted to US$ 61,641,500.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The amortized cost of the 2007 Notes is based on a discounted cash flow at an effective interest rate of 7.942%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<U>
	Covenants
</U>
	:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The 2007 Notes contain certain restrictive covenants that, among other things, limit the ability of the Company to (i) incur additional indebtedness, (ii) pay dividend, (iii) issue guarantees, (iv) dispose certain assets and (v) make certain related party transactions. The Company was in compliance with all covenants of the 2007 Notes as of the December 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The foregoing limitations are subject to exceptions as set forth in the Indenture. For example, the Company may incur in additional indebtedness as long as (i) after issuing it, the consolidated coverage ratio (calculated as the quotient of the consolidated adjusted EBITDA -earnings before financial results, income tax, depreciation and amortization-) and the consolidated interest expense) is equal or higher than 2.0:1; and (ii) the consolidated debt ratio (calculated as the quotient of the consolidated debt and the consolidated EBITDA) is equal or lower than 3.75:1; (ii) it is incurred to refinance outstanding debt and (iii) it is originated in advances from customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Additionally, the Company may pay dividends as long as (i) the Company is not in default under 2007 Notes, (ii) immediately after any dividend payment, the Company would be able to incur in additional indebtedness pursuant to item (i) and (ii) of the preceding paragraph.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<U>
	Issuance of notes under the 2014 Global Program (the &#147;2014 Program&#148;):
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The 2014 Program provides for the issuance of up to a maximum principal amount of US$400 million in notes, and was authorized by resolutions of an Extraordinary Shareholders&#146; Meeting dated April 25, 2013, and by resolutions of its Board of Directors adopted on July 23, 2013 and December 23, 2013. The program was also authorized by the CNV on January 3, 2014, after the issuance of Resolution No. 17,262.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As it is mentioned above, on January 10, 2014 TGS launched an offer for a voluntary exchange. The exchange offer settled on February 7, 2014. TGS accepted 67% of the 2007 Notes. For this reason, on February 7, 2014, the Company issued its 2014 Notes in aggregate principal amount of US$255,451,506 under its 2014 Program. The main conditions of 2014 Notes are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>

	None
</P>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The 2014 Notes are traded in the BCBA, the MAE and the Euro MTF of the Luxembourg Exchange.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The terms and conditions of the 2014 Notes are similar to those applied to the 2007 Notes, having not changed financial covenants with respect to those effective for the 2007 Notes. According to the criteria established by IAS 39, the exchange offer was not accounted for as an extinguishment of financial liabilities, and thus, the costs paid are amortized over the remaining life of the 2014 Notes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The amortized cost are based on cash flows discounted at an effective rate of 10.126%.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<U>
	Other Loans:
</U>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On November 22, 2013, the Company entered into a loan with Itau Bank for Ps. 20.0 million. The loan bears interest at an annual fixed rate of 15.25% payable on a monthly basis. The loan has a repayment schedule with 25 equal and monthly installments and final maturity in November 2016. The first installment is in November 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On December 3, 2013, the Company entered into a loan with Macro Bank for Ps. 10.0 million. The loan bears interest at an annual fixed rate of 15.25% payable on a monthly basis. The loan has a repayment schedule with 34 monthly installments as from July 2014 and final maturity in April 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The fair value of such loans is equivalent to their book value. The amortized cost are based on discounted cash flows at an effective rate of 15.25% for the loans received from Banco Macro S.A. and Banco Itau Argentina S.A.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The current terms of the Company&#146;s interest- bearing borrowings as of December 31, 2014 has been reviewed and compared to the market pricing at year&#146;s end, and the carrying value is considered to represent a reasonable approximation to fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:46.933PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
<B>
	13.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:46.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:37.733PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	INCOME TAX AND DEFERRED TAX
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX">
	The reconciliation between the tax computed for tax purposes and the income tax expense charged to the statement of comprehensive income in the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX; PADDING-LEFT:28.4PX" ALIGN=CENTER>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX">
	The analysis of the net deferred tax assets and liabilities is as follows:
</P>

</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:13.333PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX; TEXT-INDENT:48PX">
	The components of the net deferred tax assets and liabilities as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 are the following:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:51PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS101.GIF" ALT="[TGS101.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=225.133 WIDTH=567.133>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX">
	The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the years in which those temporary differences become recoverable. Management considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income and tax planning in making these assessments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX">
	Income tax expense computed at the statutory tax rate on pre-tax income differs from the income tax expense for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS103.GIF" ALT="[TGS103.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=133.533 WIDTH=567.133>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX">
	Cumulative tax loss carryforwards recorded by the Company that are pending at year end may be offset against taxable income in future years, according to the following detail:
</P>

</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
</TD>

</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX">
	The realization of deferred tax assets, including those mentioned losses, depends on the generation of future taxable income during the years in which temporary differences become deductible. To determine the realization of deferred tax assets, the Company considers the reversal of deferred tax liabilities, tax planning and projections of future taxable profits based on its best estimate in accordance with the guidelines set out in Note 5.d). Based on these projections, the Company estimates that as of December 31, 2015 it is probable that all deferred tax assets are made.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:46.933PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
<B>
	14.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:46.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:37.733PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	PROVISIONS
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-SIZE:9PT" ALIGN=CENTER>
	&nbsp;
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS105.GIF" ALT="[TGS105.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=375.533 WIDTH=403.267>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
	The total amount of the Provisions are included in current liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:46.933PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
<B>
	15.
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:46.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:37.733PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<B>
<U>
	FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT
</U>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; WIDTH:24PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:24PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
<I>
	Financial risk factors
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company&#146;s activities and the market in which it operates expose it to a series of financial risks: market risk (including foreign exchange risk, cash flows interest rate risk, and commodity price risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. To that extent, the Company has different policies adopted to mitigate its exposure to financial risks.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.1
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Foreign exchange risk
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company is primarily exposed to the fluctuation of the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar against the Argentine Peso due to the fact that almost its entire financial indebtedness is denominated in U.S. dollars.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As regards to the revenue derived from the Natural Gas Transportation segment, under Public Emergency and Reform of the Foreign Exchange System Law No. 25,561 (the &#147;Public Emergency Law&#148;), the tariffs charged by the Company are currently denominated in Argentine pesos. In accordance with the Public Emergency Law, in January 2002, public service tariffs were converted into Argentine pesos and fixed at an exchange rate of Ps. 1.00 = US$ l.00 even as the Argentine peso was allowed to devalue against the US dollar. On the other hand, revenues in US dollars derived from the Liquids Production and Commercialization segment accounted for approximately 84%, 83% and 90% of the segment&#146;s total revenues for both the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. Total revenues denominated in Argentine Pesos accounted for 39%, 35% and 29% for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Considering the net liability financial position described in the table below, the Company estimated that, other factors being constant, a 10% appreciation of the US dollar against the Argentine Peso for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 would have decreased the Company&#146;s income before tax for the year in approximately Ps. 244,418, Ps. 196,725 and Ps. 187,569, respectively. A 10% depreciation of the US dollar against the Argentine Peso would have an equal and opposite effect on the income statement. Actual results may differ significantly from these theoretical sensitivity scenarios.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:3.4PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS107.GIF" ALT="[TGS107.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=102.667 WIDTH=504.267>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; FONT-SIZE:9.5PT">
<I>
	Derivative Financial Instruments
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	To mitigate the foreign exchange risk, during the years 2015 and 2014, the Company entered into forward purchase of US dollars, as well as investments in mutual funds linked to the US dollar in order to cover the exposure to the risk associated with the foreign exchange rate derived from its financial debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	At the end of this year, the net position is buying US dollars amounting to US$ 52.5 million at a weighted average exchange rate of Ps. 11.65 which due in May 2016. The fair value of these contracts as of December 31, 2015 amounted to a net asset position of Ps. 128,125, which is disclosed under the item &#147;Derivative financial instruments&#148; in the Statement of Financial Position. Such contracts are guaranteed by Ps. 29,910 which are disclosed under &quot;Other Receivables.&quot;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.2
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Interest rate risk
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company&#146;s interest rate risk arises from long-term borrowings. Borrowings issued at floating rates expose the Company to cash flow interest rate risk. Borrowings issued at fixed rates expose the Company to fair value interest rate risk. The interest rate profile of the Company's borrowings is set out in Note 12.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Currently, the Company&#146;s exposure to cash flow interest rate risk is limited due to the fact that 100% of its outstanding financial indebtedness bears fixed interest rates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As far as interest-bearing financial assets, the exposure to interest rate risk is limited to the financial assets of the Company which bear variable interest rate. Most of the financial assets of the Company bear fix rate interests. &nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The following table shows a breakdown of the Company&#146;s fixed-rate and floating-rate financial assets and liabilities as of December 31, 2015 and 2014:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:47.267PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS109.GIF" ALT="[TGS109.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=177 WIDTH=564.4>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	In view of the nature of the Company&#146;s financial assets which bear variable interest, an immediate 100 basis points decrease in the interest rate would not have a significant impact on the total value of the financial assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.3
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Commodity price risk
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Commercial operations performed by the Company in its Liquids Production and Commercialization segment are affected by a number of factors beyond its control, including changes in the international prices of the products sold, and government regulations on prices, taxes and other charges, among others.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The sale prices of propane and butane (&#147;LPG&#148;) and natural gasoline the Company exports in its Liquids Production and Commercialization segment are referenced to international prices (Mont Belvieu for the LPG and NWE ARA for the natural gasoline). These prices have historically been cyclical, reflecting overall economic conditions and changes in capacity within the industry, which may affect the profitability of companies engaged in this business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Based on the volume of sales for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, the Company estimated that, other factors being constant, a decrease of US$50/ton in the international price of LPG and natural gasoline, respectively, would have decreased the Company&#146;s net comprehensive income in its Liquids Production and Commercialization segment in Ps. 151,299, Ps. 69,228 and Ps. 36,723, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	A US$ 50/ton increase would have an equal and opposite effect on the statement of comprehensive income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company does not currently use derivative financial instruments to mitigate the risks associated with international commodity price fluctuations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	On the other hand, the price at which the Company sells ethane to PBB Polisur S.A. (&#147;Polisur&#148;) under an agreement expiring December 31, 2015 is subject to an annual adjustment process based on various factors including the Produce Price Index (&#147;PPI&#148;), natural gas price, the quality of the ethane shipped by the Company and the transportation tariffs and charges. Accordingly, the Company does not consider that the sale price of ethane poses a significant risk to the Company.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Furthermore, due to the sharp decrease in the international price of the ethane, the gap between the selling price of TGS has increased against the price offer by the alternative Polisur&#146;s alternative supplier. This gap, plus the expiration of the contract, it would be expected that the risk of lower &nbsp;price or volumes of ethane sales could be considered high.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.4
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Credit risk
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company&#146;s exposures to credit risk takes the form of a loss that would be recognized if counterparties failed to, or were unable to, meet their payment obligations. These risks may arise in certain agreements in relation to amounts owed for physical product sales, the use of derivative instruments, and the investment of surplus cash balances. This risk mainly results from economic and financial factors or from a possible default of counterparty.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company is subject to credit risk arising from outstanding receivables, cash and cash equivalents and deposits with banks and financial institutions, and from the use of derivative financial instruments. The Company&#146;s policy is to manage credit exposure to trading counterparties within defined trading limits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	If any of the Company&#146;s customers are independently rated, these ratings are used. Otherwise, if there is no independent rating, the Company assesses the credit quality of the customer taking into account its financial position, past experience and other factors. The Company may seek cash collateral, letter of credit or parent company guarantees, as considered appropriate.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014 the balance of current and non-current trade receivables, net of allowances of doubtful accounts are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS111.GIF" ALT="[TGS111.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=102.667 WIDTH=491.733>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company, in the normal course of business, renders natural gas transportation services, principally to gas distribution companies, and to Petrobras Argentina (one of the shareholders of CIESA). </P>

<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Below is a detail of the maturities of the financial assets included in: (i) cash and cash equivalents, (ii) loans granted to related parties, (iii) other financial assets at fair value through profit or loss, (iv) trade receivables, (v) other receivables and (vi) derivate financial instruments, as of December 31, 2015 and 2014:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS113.GIF" ALT="[TGS113.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=394.8 WIDTH=490>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS115.GIF" ALT="[TGS115.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=461.8 WIDTH=498.333>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company is exposed to counterparty credit risk on cash and cash equivalent balances. The Company holds cash on deposit with a number of financial institutions. The Company manages its credit risk exposure by limiting individual deposits to clearly defined limits in various financial institutions. The Company considers that this risk is limited because it has short-term funds policies whose main objective is to obtain an adequate return in terms of market characteristics and minimizing exposure. The Company only deposits with high quality banks and financial institutions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The maximum exposure to credit risk is represented by the carrying amount of cash and cash equivalents in the statement of financial position. Below we include information regarding their credit rating:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.5
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Liquidity risk
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company is exposed to liquidity risks, including: risks associated with refinancing borrowings as they mature, the risk that borrowing facilities are not available to meet cash requirements and the risk that financial assets cannot readily be converted to cash without loss of value. Failure to manage financing risks could have a material impact on the Company&#146;s cash flow and statement of financial position.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Prudent liquidity risk management includes managing the profile of debt maturities and funding sources and close oversight of cash flows projections. The Company has funding policies whose main objectives are to meet the financing needs at the lowest cost possible according to market conditions. The main objective of the Company is its financial solvency. Given the current financial market conditions, the Company believes that the availability of resources and the positive cash flow from operations are sufficient to meet its current obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The table below includes a detail of the maturities of the obligations corresponding to financial liabilities corresponding to: trade payables, payroll payables, other payables, derivative financial instruments and loans as of December 31, 2015 and 2014. The amounts disclosed in the table are the contractual undiscounted cash flows and as a result, they do not reconcile to the amounts disclosed on the statement of financial position.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
	F-15

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	1.6
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Capital risk management
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company&#146;s objectives when managing capital are to safeguard the Company&#146;s ability to continue as a going concern in order to provide returns for shareholders and benefits for other stakeholders and to maintain an optimal credit quality and capital structure to reduce the cost of capital.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
	The Company seeks to maintain a level of cash generation from operating activities, which may allow it to meet all of its commitments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The Company monitors capital on the basis of the gearing ratio. This ratio is calculated as total financial debt (including current and non-current loans as shown in the consolidated statement of financial position, if applicable) divided by total capital. Total capital is calculated as equity, as shown in the consolidated statement of financial position, plus total debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During the year ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, the gearing ratio was as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; WIDTH:24PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
<I>
	2
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:24PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
<I>
	FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS BY CATEGORY AND HIERARCHY
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	2.1
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Financial instrument categories
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Accounting policies for the categorization of financial instruments are explained in Note 4.d. According to the provisions of IFRS 7 and IAS 32, non-financial assets and liabilities such as property, plant and equipment, investments in associates, inventories, advances from customers, deferred income tax, taxes and social taxes payables and provisions are not included.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The categories of financial assets and liabilities as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS121.GIF" ALT="[TGS121.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=442.467 WIDTH=519.267>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS123.GIF" ALT="[TGS123.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=466.533 WIDTH=532.533>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:24PX; WIDTH:48PX; FLOAT:LEFT">
	2.2
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:48PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Fair value measurement hierarchy and estimates
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	According to IFRS 13, the fair value hierarchy introduces three levels of inputs based on the lowest level of input significant to the overall fair value. These levels are:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE=MARGIN-TOP:6.667PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-1PT;FONT-SIZE:1PT />
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:42.933PX; FONT-FAMILY:SYMBOL; FLOAT:LEFT">
	&#183;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:6.667PX; PADDING-LEFT:42.933PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Level 1: includes financial assets and liabilities whose fair values are estimated using quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets and liabilities. The instruments included in this level primarily include balances in mutual funds and public or private bonds listed on the BCBA. Additionally within this level, the Company included derivative financial instruments because the settlement date thereof coincided with the closing date of the fiscal year. For the calculation of fair value, the corresponding quoted price was obtained.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:42.933PX; FONT-FAMILY:SYMBOL; CLEAR:LEFT; FLOAT:LEFT">
	&#183;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:42.933PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	Level 2: includes financial assets and liabilities whose fair value is estimated using different assumptions quoted prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (i.e. as prices) or indirectly (for example, derived from prices). Within this level, the Company includes those derivate financial instruments for which it was not able to find an active market.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX; MARGIN-BOTTOM:-2PX; TEXT-INDENT:18.933PX; WIDTH:42.933PX; FONT-FAMILY:SYMBOL; FLOAT:LEFT">
	&#183;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:42.933PX; TEXT-INDENT:-2PX">
	Level 3: includes financial instruments for which the assumptions used in estimating fair value are not based on observable market information.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; CLEAR:LEFT">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	During 2015, there were neither transfers between the different hierarchies of fair values nor reclassifications between financial instruments categories.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The table below shows different assets and liabilities at their fair value classified by hierarchy as of December 31, 2015 and 2014:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS125.GIF" ALT="[TGS125.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=138.6 WIDTH=566.867>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; FONT-FAMILY:CG TIMES,TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN=CENTER>
	&nbsp;
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS127.GIF" ALT="[TGS127.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=191.8 WIDTH=567.267>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The carrying amount of the financial assets and liabilities is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014, the carrying amount of certain financial instruments used by the Company including cash, cash equivalents, other investments, receivables, payables and short term loans are representative of fair value because of the short-term nature of these instruments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX; PADDING-LEFT:18.933PX; PADDING-RIGHT:-0.067PX" ALIGN=JUSTIFY>
	The estimated fair value of other Non-current assets and Other loans does not differ significantly from the carrying amount. The following table reflects the carrying amount and estimated fair value of the 2007 Notes and 2014 Notes at December 31, 2015 and 2014 based on their quoted market price:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>

</P>

<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS129.GIF" ALT="[TGS129.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=70.133 WIDTH=456.4>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX">
<BR>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0PX" ALIGN=CENTER>
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2016/05/02/0000931427-16-000027_TGS131.GIF" ALT="[TGS131.GIF]" ALIGN=TOP HEIGHT=70.133 WIDTH=456.4>
</P>

<BR>
</P>

<BR>
</P>
